descr.p: The libtar units provides 2 classes to read and write .tar archives: class can be used to read a tar file, and the class can be used to write a tar file. The unit was implemented originally by Stefan Heymann.

element.name: TTarPermission
element.descr: TTarPermission denotes part of a files permission as it stored in the .tar archive. Each of these enumerated constants correspond with one of the permission bits from a UNIX file permission.

element.name: TTarPermission.tpReadByOther
element.short: Other people can read the file.

element.name: TTarPermission.tpWriteByOther
element.short: Other people can write the file

element.name: TTarPermission.tpExecuteByOther
element.short: Other people can execute the file

element.name: TTarPermissions
element.short: Complete set of permissions for file
element.descr: TTarPermissions describes the complete set of permissions that a file has. It is used in the Permissions field of the record.

element.name: TFileType
element.descr: TFileType describes the file type of a file in the archive. It is used in the FileType field of the record.

element.name: TFileType.ftVolumeHeader
element.short: Volume header, can appear only as first entry in the archive

element.name: TTarMode
element.descr: TTarMode describes extra file modes. It is used in the Mode field of the record.

element.name: TTarModes
element.descr: TTarModes denotes the full set of permission bits for the file in the field Mode field of the record.

element.name: TTarDirRec
element.descr: TTarDirRec describes an entry in the tar archive. It is similar to a directory entry as in TSearchRec, and is returned by the call.

element.name: TTarDirRec.FilePos
element.short: Start position of file in archive

element.name: TTarArchive
element.short: Class to examine and read tar archives
element.descr: TTarArchive is the class used to read and examine .tar archives. It can be constructed from a stream or from a filename. Creating an instance will not perform any operation on the stream yet.

element.name: TTarArchive.Create
element.short: Create a new instance of the archive
element.descr: Create can be used to create a new instance of TTarArchive using either a Stream TStream descendent or using a name of a file to open: FileName. In case of the filename, an open mode can be specified.
element.errors: In case a filename is specified and the file cannot be opened, an exception will occur.

element.name: TTarArchive.Create.Filename
element.short: Filename to open and read archive from

element.name: TTarArchive.Destroy
element.descr: Destroy closes the archive stream (if it created a stream) and cleans up the TTarArchive instance.

element.name: TTarArchive.Reset
element.descr: Reset sets the archive file position on the beginning of the archive.

element.name: TTarArchive.FindNext
element.descr: FindNext positions the file pointer on the next archive entry, and returns all information about the entry in DirRec. It returns True if the operation was successful, or False if not (for instance, when the end of the archive was reached).
element.errors: In case there are no more entries, False is returned.

element.name: TTarArchive.FindNext.Result
element.short: True if the next entry was found.

element.name: TTarArchive.ReadFile
element.short: Read a file from the archive

descr.p: ReadFile can be used to read the current file in the archive. It can be called after the archive was successfully positioned on an entry in the archive. The file can be read in various ways:

ul.li: directly in a memory buffer. No checks are performed to see whether the buffer points to enough memory.
It can be copied to a Stream.
It can be copied to a file with name FileName.
The file content can be copied to a string

element.errors: An exception may occur if the buffer is not large enough, or when the file specified in filename cannot be opened.

element.name: TTarArchive.ReadFile.Buffer
element.short: Memory buffer to copy file contents to.

element.name: TTarArchive.ReadFile.Stream
element.short: Stream to copy file contents to.

element.name: TTarArchive.ReadFile.Filename
element.short: Filename for file in which to write file content.

element.name: TTarArchive.GetFilePos
element.descr: GetFilePos returns the position in the tar archive in Current and the complete archive size in Size.

element.name: TTarArchive.SetFilePos
element.descr: SetFilePos can be used to set the absolute position in the tar archive.

element.name: TTarWriter
element.descr: TTarWriter can be used to create .tar archives. It can be created using a filename, in which case the archive will be written to the filename, or it can be created using a stream, in which case the archive will be written to the stream - for instance a compression stream.

element.name: TTarWriter.Create
element.descr: Create creates a new TTarWriter instance. This will start a new .tar archive. The archive will be written to the TargetStream stream or to a file with name TargetFileName, which will be opened with filemode Mode.
element.errors: In case TargetFileName cannot be opened, an exception will be raised.

element.name: TTarWriter.Create.Mode
element.short: Mode to open target file with. File must be writable

element.name: TTarWriter.Destroy
element.short: Close archive and clean up TTarWriter
element.descr: Destroy will close the archive (i.e. it writes the end-of-archive marker, if it was not yet written), and then frees the TTarWriter instance.

element.name: TTarWriter.AddFile
element.short: Add a file to the archive

descr.p: AddFile adds a file to the archive: the contents is read from FileName. Optionally, an alternative filename can be specified in TarFileName. This name should contain only forward slash path separators. If it is not specified, the name will be computed from FileName.
The archive entry is written with the current owner data and permissions.

element.errors: If FileName cannot be opened, an exception will be raised.

element.name: TTarWriter.AddFile.Filename
element.short: File to add to the archive

descr.p: AddStream will add the contents of Stream to the archive. The Stream will not be reset: only the contents of the stream from the current position will be written to the archive. The entry will be written with file name TarFileName. This name should contain only forward slash path separators. The entry will be written with timestamp FileDateGmt.
The archive entry is written with the current owner data and permissions.

element.name: TTarWriter.AddStream.Stream
element.short: Stream data to be added to archive

descr.p: AddString adds the string Contents as the data of an entry with file name TarFileName. This name should contain only forward slash path separators. The entry will be written with timestamp FileDateGmt.
The archive entry is written with the current owner data and permissions.
AddDir adds a directory entry to the archive. The entry is written with name DirName, maximum directory size MaxDirSize (0 means unlimited) and timestamp DateGmt.
Note that this call only adds an entry for a directory to the archive: if DirName is an existing directory, it does not write all files in the directory to the archive.
The directory entry is written with the current owner data and permissions.

element.name: TTarWriter.AddSymbolicLink
element.short: Add a symbolic link to the archive

descr.p: AddSymbolicLink adds a symbolic link entry to the archive, with name FileName, pointing to LinkName. The entry is written with timestamp DateGmt.
The link entry is written with the current owner data and permissions.
AddLink adds a hard link entry to the archive. The entry has name FileName, timestamp DateGmt and points to LinkName.
The link entry is written with the current owner data and permissions.
AddVolumeHeader adds a volume header entry to the archive. The entry is written with name VolumeID and timestamp DateGmt.
The volume header entry is written with the current owner data and permissions.
Finalize writes the end-of-archive marker to the archive. No more entries can be added after Finalize was called.
If the TTarWriter instance is destroyed, it will automatically call finalize if finalize was not yet called.

element.name: TTarWriter.Permissions
element.descr: Permissions is used for the permissions field of the archive entries.

element.name: TTarWriter.UID
element.descr: UID is used for the UID field of the archive entries.

element.name: TTarWriter.GID
element.descr: GID is used for the GID field of the archive entries.

element.name: TTarWriter.UserName
element.descr: UserName is used for the UserName field of the archive entries.

element.name: TTarWriter.GroupName
element.descr: GroupName is used for the GroupName field of the archive entries.

element.name: TTarWriter.Mode
element.descr: Mode is used for the Mode field of the archive entries.

element.name: TTarWriter.Magic
element.descr: Magic is used for the Magic field of the archive entries.

element.name: FILETYPE_NAME
element.descr: FILETYPE_NAME can be used to get a textual description for each of the possible entry file types.

element.name: ALL_PERMISSIONS
element.descr: ALL_PERMISSIONS is a set constant containing all possible permissions (read/write/execute, for all groups of users) for an archive entry.

element.name: READ_PERMISSIONS
element.descr: READ_PERMISSIONS is a set constant containing all possible read permissions set for an archive entry.

element.name: WRITE_PERMISSIONS
element.descr: WRITE_PERMISSIONS is a set constant containing all possible write permissions set for an archive entry.

element.name: EXECUTE_PERMISSIONS
element.descr: WRITE_PERMISSIONS is a set constant containing all possible execute permissions set for an archive entry.

element.name: PermissionString
element.short: Convert a set of permissions to a string
element.descr: PermissionString can be used to convert a set of Permissions to a string in the same format as used by the UNIX 'ls' command.

element.name: ConvertFilename
element.descr: ConvertFileName converts the file name FileName to a format allowed by the tar archive. Basically, it converts directory specifiers to forward slashes.

element.name: FileTimeGMT
element.descr: FileTimeGMT returns the timestamp of a filename (FileName must exist) or a search rec (TSearchRec) to a GMT representation that can be used in a tar entry.

element.name: FileTimeGMT.SearchRec
element.short: Searchrec from which timestamp is taken

element.name: ClearDirRec
element.descr: ClearDirRec clears the DirRec entry, it basically zeroes out all fields.
